>
> > Preliminary results don't show any significant benefit from
> speciation,
> > however I have identified a possible reason why and I have some
> avenues
> > of investigation to follow up. Basically on close inspection of
> the
> > trees I can see a large number of redundant(neutral) nodes.
> Allowing
>
>
> Can you explain a little more what a "neutral node" is? Even a
> nonfunctional node should not cause too much problem if historical
> markings are used, since you know which neutral nodes came from
> which lineages. But I am not completely clear on what these nodes
> are and how they came to be.

Due to the type of genome encoding I use it is possible to describe 
neurons that are not connected, either at all or perhaps connected but 
not in a meaningful way. That's what I mean by neutral nodes in the 
genome. Whether they are there or not does not affect a network's 
performance on a given task. So as evolution progresses it is possible 
to aggregate neutral nodes unless some mechanism is used to keep the 
numbers down. The obvious thing to do was to punish genomes with larger 
numbers of nodes therefore preventing the number of nodes spiraling out 
of control. Now it seems that although this works (it keeps the number 
of nodes down) the punishment is quite weak and therefore large numbers 
of neutral nodes are still present in my populations - thus causing the 
large differences in compatibility number - thus causing speciation 
where perhaps it shouldn't.

Now I suppose you could argue that the neutral nodes may have a positive 
purpose in that they may get connected to in future mutations. At the 
moment though I just see the same basic genome being 'decorated' with 
neutral nodes in many different ways - causing genomes that essentialy 
describe the same network to be placed in different species.


>
> One thing to consider about speciation is that it goes hand in hand
> with complexification. In other words, speciation facilitates
> starting the entire population with a very small genome and
> complexifying from there. But if you *don't* start that way, then
> the effects of speciation are questionable, since many of the
> species will be protected without justification just because they
> happen to be in the initial population. 

I'm not sure I agree. Although we give weaker genomes a chance by 
protecting them in a species, overall, weak genomes and weak species 
will be culled from the population. So if I create a population of 
random genomes then they will all be in a species of one to begin with - 
and the stronger genomes will progressively take over the population 
based on their relative fitness.

> Does your system start
> minimally?


I have initialisation routines for both ways - random and a population 
asexually reproduced from a single 'seed' genome.

> [Stuff about a stepped punishment factor ]
>
> This is a sensible fix, but NEAT for example was designed to avoid
> the need for this kind of ad hoc fitness tinkering. If you start
> minimally and speciate, the system should tend towards minimality
> without the need for penalities.

I think I'm missing something! How do you prevent NEAT genomes/networks 
from growing out of control? After all a network may have thousands of 
neurons but only a couple of them may actually be performing the task at 
hand. Perhaps this is just a consequence of NEAT's speed - it doesn't 
(hasn't had to) evolve long enough to fall into this trap? How long do 
NEAT evolution runs normally last? From what I know so far I can only 
imagine that if we gave NEAT a problem that was too hard to solve and 
left it to evolve for any considerable time then the genomes would just 
keep getting longer - I'm more than happy to be proved wrong though :)


Colin.
